messageBody:
On 13.1.2008 Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> It seems to me that some, though perhaps not all, aspects
> of Senior QS could serve as an aid to reading a long text.
> Consider the word "end". Not only is it a common word, but
> it comprises a letter sequence that occurs frequently in
> the beginning, middle and end of longer words (e.g.
> endurance, commendable, trend). As I have argued before, a
> word such as "end" would look quite strange if written
> with #23 instead of alt-#23, and I further contend that
> the alternates for #23 and #36 should be included in
> Junior QS. So the proper spelling (using revised names)
> would be Ed+Noon+Deed. Now, once you begin to use half-
> letters, it becomes immediately natural to use half-Deed
> in "end": Ed+Noon+half-Deed. This quickly becomes a
> recognizable unit in longer words. It would take
> experimentation to prove it, but my guess is that this
> particular combination would only improve reading speed
> and comprehension.
>

As a long term shorthand user I can confirm that you're
probably right. The recognition factor is what makes special
'signs' for recurrent morphemes so effective in shorthand.
One reads by recognizing word outlines rather than letter
combos even in Roman, certainly in Latin cursive.

/BP
